pullRequest.body:
Define group objects in cartesian monoidal categories.

Show that the associativity diagram of a group object is always cartesian and deduce that morphisms of group objects commute with taking inverses.

Show that a finite-product-preserving functor takes group objects to group objects.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

- [x] depends on: #21509

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#21509~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

Thanks for the work! I didn't know you were working on this, and was planning to work with PKU students to define group schemes as group objects in the category over a base scheme (with the cartesian monoidal structure). It seems mathlib doesn't have the Monoid instance on `X âŸ¶ M` if `M` is a monoid object (with cartesian product) and `X` is arbitrary. Do you also have group schemes in mind and do you plan to do anything about that? You did touch the cartesian file, but aren't adding much.

For elliptic curves we might need "MulAction objects" which are actually two objects `M` and `S` in a category equipped with a morphism `M Ã— S âŸ¶ S` satisfying axioms, where `M` is a monoid/group object. I'm wondering whether we can use some automation to get the MulAction of `X âŸ¶ M` on `X âŸ¶ S`; I don't know whether the work of @adamtopaz [on Lawvere theory](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=24T339nz9ik) is relevant here.

The next goal would be the anti-equivalence between the category of affine group schemes to [HopfAlgebraCat](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/HopfAlgebraCat/Basic.html#HopfAlgebraCat), as Hopf algebras can be seen as cogroup objects (w.r.t. coproduct, i.e. tensor product) in the category of R-algebras. (On the other hand R-algebras can be seen as monoid objects in R-Mod w.r.t. tensor product, which is super confusing ...)

> It seems mathlib doesn't have the Monoid instance on `X âŸ¶ M` if `M` is a monoid object (with cartesian product) and `X` is arbitrary

#21394

Sorry, should have given a more precise link
Is [this](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/81f60827e553c7ea63a8ffbbf4731b5be5026dba/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Monoidal/Yoneda.lean#L64) not what you are talking about?
Thanks! I should have spotted it. I'm surprised `Mon_ C` isn't just defined to be `X : C` + `Mon_Class X`.

> I'm surprised `Mon_ C` isn't just defined to be `X : C` + `Mon_Class X`.

I think the reason for this is simply that `Mon_` is much older than `Mon_Class` and no one has done the refactor yet.
LGTM and I would want this in mathlib very much but I don't think I am familiar enough with the monoidal category library to maintainer merge this.
LGTM and I would want this in mathlib very much but I don't think I am familiar enough with the monoidal category library to maintainer merge this.
We have `PreservesFiniteProducts` for this I think.

Thanks for the work! I didn't know you were working on this, and was planning to work with PKU students to define group schemes as group objects in the category over a base scheme (with the cartesian monoidal structure). It seems mathlib doesn't have the Monoid instance on `X âŸ¶ M` if `M` is a monoid object (with cartesian product) and `X` is arbitrary. Do you also have group schemes in mind and do you plan to do anything about that? You did touch the cartesian file, but aren't adding much.

For elliptic curves we might need "MulAction objects" which are actually two objects `M` and `S` in a category equipped with a morphism `M Ã— S âŸ¶ S` satisfying axioms, where `M` is a monoid/group object. I'm wondering whether we can use some automation to get the MulAction of `X âŸ¶ M` on `X âŸ¶ S`; I don't know whether the work of @adamtopaz [on Lawvere theory](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=24T339nz9ik) is relevant here.

The next goal would be the anti-equivalence between the category of affine group schemes to [HopfAlgebraCat](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Category/HopfAlgebraCat/Basic.html#HopfAlgebraCat), as Hopf algebras can be seen as cogroup objects (w.r.t. coproduct, i.e. tensor product) in the category of R-algebras. (On the other hand R-algebras can be seen as monoid objects in R-Mod w.r.t. tensor product, which is super confusing ...)
